headline: Western U.S. has a voice to break through the D.C. bureaucracy
author: Debbie Lesko and Dan Newhouse
sentences: As one of seven states in the Colorado River Basin, it is crucial for our colleagues in Congress to understand how Arizona and the surrounding region – led by collaborative agencies such as CAP – work in partnership to ensure a reliable water supply for our communities in the face of challenging water conditions.

In addition to creating nearly 4,000 jobs and contributing over $60 billion in economic value for the state of Arizona, the project would have produced a stable, domestic source of copper, an essential mineral used to manufacture medical equipment, clean energy technologies and mobile devices.

Providing water for more than 80% of the state’s population, 11 Native American tribes, and 350,000 acres of irrigated agriculture, CAP is a 336-mile long system of aqueducts, pumping plants, pipelines, and tunnels stretching from Lake Havasu all the way to its terminus just south of Tucson.

We hosted a policy roundtable to hear from local experts about the need to modernize western water infrastructure and how we can work in Congress to address the historic drought conditions communities are experiencing.

The United States imposes the strongest environmental and labor standards for mining in the world, and we have the potential to develop a safe and secure supply of critical minerals right here at home.

As Members of the Congressional Western Caucus, we are proud to serve as a voice for those who feel forgotten by bureaucrats in D.C. and stand for the values and freedoms we enjoy throughout the West.
We discussed the continued need to promote safe, responsible domestic mineral development, and we heard from state leaders about how we can support Arizona’s agriculture industry and public lands.
Resolution Copper, one of the largest potential copper development projects in the world, has been undergoing rigorous permitting processes and environmental review for nearly two decades.

By U.S. Reps. Debbie Lesko and Dan Newhouse
It is increasingly clear on issues ranging from energy independence to national security that Arizona’s priorities are America’s priorities.
Opportunities like these are invaluable as we push for commonsense policies and reforms in our nation’s capital, and we will continue working to ensure Arizona’s priorities are heard.

Lesson on the supply of western water
Following the roundtable, we toured the Central Arizona Project (CAP), the single largest resource for renewable water supplies in Arizona.
Our cause is safe, responsible and domestic development of minerals and energy resources, and we strongly support local conservation of our public lands and water supplies.
We hope this tour will help us shed light on the Biden Administration’s hypocrisy when it comes to domestic mineral supplies and the need for commonsense permitting reform.
We are the Congressional Western Caucus, lawmakers who truly understand from experience the impacts the federal government can have on our lands, waters and energy supply.
Unfortunately, Resolution Copper is just one of many hostages the Biden administration has taken in the last year as part of its mission to handcuff American mining.
Still, during his first months in office, President Biden rescinded a previously established environmental review, bringing the project to a screeching halt.

So we brought members of Congress, staff and stakeholders here in early March to see these priorities up close.
